object.property: This module defines agent capabilities for deployed VMware agents by release.
VMware, Inc 3401 Hillview Ave Palo Alto, CA 94304 Tel: 1-877-486-9273 or 650-427-5000 Fax: 650-427-5001 Web: http://communities.vmware.com/community/developer/forums/managementapi
This module defines agent capabilities for deployed VMware agents by release.
Release 4.0.x for VMware ESX. The SNMP agent is now part of the hostd process
Release 4.0.x for VMware ESX. The SNMP agent is now part of the hostd process
Release 4.1.x for VMware ESX, the SNMP agent is now a subsystem in the hostd process on ESXi.
Release 4.1.x for VMware ESX, the SNMP agent is now a subsystem in the hostd process on ESXi.
Release 5.0.x for VMware ESXi. The SNMPv1/v2c agent is a subsystem in the hostd process
Release 5.0.x for VMware ESXi. The SNMPv1/v2c agent is a subsystem in the hostd process

Release 5.1.x for VMware ESXi supports SNMPv1, SNMPv2c, and SNMPv3 with a stand-alone snmpd process. This agent supports read-only protocol operations. This implies that configuring the SNMPv3 Agent can not be done via SET operations. Hence IETF standard SNMPv3 agent configuration mibs are not provided. SNMPv3 protocol is fully supported once configured via the CLI command interface (esxcli system snmp) command set or host profiles. Lastly this SNMP agent provides one read-only view of the entire system to which all SNMPv3 users configured are assigned.

Release 5.1.x for VMware ESXi supports SNMPv1, SNMPv2c, and SNMPv3 with a stand-alone snmpd process. This agent supports read-only protocol operations. This implies that configuring the SNMPv3 Agent can not be done via SET operations. Hence IETF standard SNMPv3 agent configuration mibs are not provided. SNMPv3 protocol is fully supported once configured via the CLI command interface (esxcli system snmp) command set or host profiles. Lastly this SNMP agent provides one read-only view of the entire system to which all SNMPv3 users configured are assigned.

Release 5.5 for VMware ESXi supports SNMPv1, SNMPv2c, and SNMPv3 with a stand-alone snmpd process.
This release features support for monitoring multiple IP Stacks. The standard IP-MIB, UDP-MIB, and TCP-MIB may be used with a context set to the IP Stack Name as found in ENTITY-MIB entLogicalTable or via command: esxcli network ip netstack list An example using net-snmp's snmpwalk command:: snmpwalk -v2c -n defaultTcpipStack ip
No vDR instrumentation is yet available.
This agent supports read-only protocol operations. This implies that configuring the SNMPv3 Agent can not be done via SET operations. Hence IETF standard SNMPv3 agent configuration mibs are not provided. The SNMPv3 protocol is fully supported once configured via the CLI command interface (esxcli system snmp) command set or vCenter Server host profiles. Lastly this SNMP agent provides one read-only view of the entire system to which all SNMPv3 users configured are assigned.

Release 5.5 for VMware ESXi supports SNMPv1, SNMPv2c, and SNMPv3 with a stand-alone snmpd process.
This release features support for monitoring multiple IP Stacks. The standard IP-MIB, UDP-MIB, and TCP-MIB may be used with a context set to the IP Stack Name as found in ENTITY-MIB entLogicalTable or via command: esxcli network ip netstack list An example using net-snmp's snmpwalk command:: snmpwalk -v2c -n defaultTcpipStack ip
No vDR instrumentation is yet available.
This agent supports read-only protocol operations. This implies that configuring the SNMPv3 Agent can not be done via SET operations. Hence IETF standard SNMPv3 agent configuration mibs are not provided. The SNMPv3 protocol is fully supported once configured via the CLI command interface (esxcli system snmp) command set or vCenter Server host profiles. Lastly this SNMP agent provides one read-only view of the entire system to which all SNMPv3 users configured are assigned.
This MIB module provides instrumentation of a CIM Object Manager.
VMware, Inc 3401 Hillview Ave Palo Alto, CA 94304 Tel: 1-877-486-9273 or 650-427-5000 Fax: 650-427-5001 Web: http://communities.vmware.com/community/developer/forums/managementapi
This MIB module provides instrumentation of a CIM Object Manager.
This notification, if the agent is so configured, will be sent on a periodic basis to indicate cimom indication delivery is functioning.
This notification, if the agent is so configured, will be sent on a periodic basis to indicate cimom indication delivery is functioning.
This MIB module identifies hardware components of a machine as provided by IPMI.
VMware, Inc 3401 Hillview Ave Palo Alto, CA 94304 Tel: 1-877-486-9273 or 650-427-5000 Fax: 650-427-5001 Web: http://communities.vmware.com/community/developer/forums/managementapi
This MIB module identifies hardware components of a machine as provided by IPMI.
Parent of all ESX specific notifications (traps, informs).
Parent of all ESX specific notifications (traps, informs).

The identifying information of the entity (ie, the instance) for which this notification is generated. The property contains the CIM path of an CIM object instance, encoded as a string parameter - if the instance is modeled in the CIM Schema. If not a CIM instance, the property contains some identifying string that names the entity for which the Alert is generated. The path or identifying string is formatted per the AlertingElementFormat property.

The identifying information of the entity (ie, the instance) for which this notification is generated. The property contains the CIM path of an CIM object instance, encoded as a string parameter - if the instance is modeled in the CIM Schema. If not a CIM instance, the property contains some identifying string that names the entity for which the Alert is generated. The path or identifying string is formatted per the AlertingElementFormat property.
The format of the AlertingManagedElement property is interpretable based upon the value of this property.
The format of the AlertingManagedElement property is interpretable based upon the value of this property.
Number of CIM Indication properties having a MappingString qualifier for which the the oid was not valid.
Number of CIM Indication properties having a MappingString qualifier for which the the oid was not valid.
Number of CIM Indication properties having a MappingString qualifier for which the cim type could not be converted to smi syntax.
Number of CIM Indication properties having a MappingString qualifier for which the cim type could not be converted to smi syntax.
Number of CIM Indication properties having a MappingString qualifier for which the cim value for the given cim type could not be converted.
Number of CIM Indication properties having a MappingString qualifier for which the cim value for the given cim type could not be converted.
A short description of the Indication.
A short description of the Indication.
One entry for each physical component reporting its status to ESX Operating System
One entry for each physical component reporting its status to ESX Operating System

The time and date the underlying event was first detected. May be set to the time the SNMP agent recieved the notification if in the incoming CIM indication the value is NULL due to the creating entity not being capable of providing this information. This value is based on the notion of local date and time of the Managed System Element generating the Indication.

The time and date the underlying event was first detected. May be set to the time the SNMP agent recieved the notification if in the incoming CIM indication the value is NULL due to the creating entity not being capable of providing this information. This value is based on the notion of local date and time of the Managed System Element generating the Indication.
Number of CIM GetClass operations over a given cim indication class and namespace could not be completed (timeout) or returned error.
Number of CIM GetClass operations over a given cim indication class and namespace could not be completed (timeout) or returned error.
Value of sysUptime when vmwHardwareStatus was obtained
Value of sysUptime when vmwHardwareStatus was obtained
Number of CIM Indications that agent did not complete receipt of.
Number of CIM Indications that agent did not complete receipt of.
Number of HTTP POST msgs containing CIM Indications in XML as received by agent.
Number of HTTP POST msgs containing CIM Indications in XML as received by agent.
Number of CIM Indications having a MappingString qualifier for which the value was not a valid oid.
Number of CIM Indications having a MappingString qualifier for which the value was not a valid oid.
A unique identifier that does not persist across management restarts
A unique identifier that does not persist across management restarts
Number of CIM indications recieved for which GetClass reported no MappingStrings qualifier and were not converted to a notification.
Number of CIM indications recieved for which GetClass reported no MappingStrings qualifier and were not converted to a notification.

The time and date of creation of the underlying Indication received by the snmp agent. The property may be set to the time SNMP agent received the notification if the entity creating the Indication is not capable of determining this information and delivers a null IndicationTime property. Note that IndicationTime may be the same for two Indications that are generated in rapid succession.

The time and date of creation of the underlying Indication received by the snmp agent. The property may be set to the time SNMP agent received the notification if the entity creating the Indication is not capable of determining this information and delivers a null IndicationTime property. Note that IndicationTime may be the same for two Indications that are generated in rapid succession.

The value of sysUptime when a conceptual row was added or deleted from this table

sysUptime when agent last received an indication.

Number of CIM indications having properties which do not have MappingString qualifier in the class definition and were not converted, sent along with the notification.

This MIB module provides instrumentation of ESX Hypervisor resources such as cpu, memory, and disk.
VMware, Inc 3401 Hillview Ave Palo Alto, CA 94304 Tel: 1-877-486-9273 or 650-427-5000 Fax: 650-427-5001 Web: http://communities.vmware.com/community/developer/forums/managementapi
This MIB module provides instrumentation of ESX Hypervisor resources such as cpu, memory, and disk.

Inventory of Host Bus Adatpers found in this system. CLI: esxcfg-scsidevs -a VIM Parent Container: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=storageSystem VIM property: hostBusAdapter MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=storageSystem&doPath=storageDeviceInfo

Inventory of Host Bus Adatpers found in this system. CLI: esxcfg-scsidevs -a VIM Parent Container: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=storageSystem VIM property: hostBusAdapter MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=storageSystem&doPath=storageDeviceInfo

Amount of memory available to run Virutal Machines and to allocate for hypervisor needs. It is computed by subtracting vmwMemCOS from vmwMemSize. The result is the amount of memory available to VMs and to the hypervisor.
To get a more accurate view of memory available to VMs the following property represents the amount of resources available for the root resource pool for running virtual machines.
VIM property: effectiveMemory MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=ha%2dcompute%2dres&doPath=summary

Amount of memory available to run Virutal Machines and to allocate for hypervisor needs. It is computed by subtracting vmwMemCOS from vmwMemSize. The result is the amount of memory available to VMs and to the hypervisor.
To get a more accurate view of memory available to VMs the following property represents the amount of resources available for the root resource pool for running virtual machines.
VIM property: effectiveMemory MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=ha%2dcompute%2dres&doPath=summary

This managed object reports memory allocated for COS, theConsole OS (aka Service Console) which is a memory region carved out of physical memory to boot a RedHat Linux distribution/provides device management interface.
Note that in the VMware ESXi product there is no COS so this will report 0.
This managed object reports the amount of physical memory allocated to the COS. VIM Parent Container: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=memorySystem VIM property: serviceConsoleReserved MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=memoryManagerSystem&doPath=consoleReservationInfo

This managed object reports memory allocated for COS, theConsole OS (aka Service Console) which is a memory region carved out of physical memory to boot a RedHat Linux distribution/provides device management interface.
Note that in the VMware ESXi product there is no COS so this will report 0.
This managed object reports the amount of physical memory allocated to the COS. VIM Parent Container: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=memorySystem VIM property: serviceConsoleReserved MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=memoryManagerSystem&doPath=consoleReservationInfo

Amount of physical memory present on machine as provided by Hypervisor. It is computed from the sum of vmwMemCOS plus unreserved property as reported VIM subsystem. Unreserved is computed from hypervisor's total number of memory pages.
VIM Parent Container: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=memorySystem VIM property: unreserved MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=memoryManagerSystem&doPath=consoleReservationInfo
For reference here two other related VIM properties: VIM property: memorySize MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=ha%2dhost&doPath=summary%2ehardware
VIM property: totalMemory MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=ha%2dcompute%2dres&doPath=summary

Amount of physical memory present on machine as provided by Hypervisor. It is computed from the sum of vmwMemCOS plus unreserved property as reported VIM subsystem. Unreserved is computed from hypervisor's total number of memory pages.
VIM Parent Container: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=memorySystem VIM property: unreserved MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=memoryManagerSystem&doPath=consoleReservationInfo
For reference here two other related VIM properties: VIM property: memorySize MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=ha%2dhost&doPath=summary%2ehardware
VIM property: totalMemory MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=ha%2dcompute%2dres&doPath=summary
Number of physical CPUs on the system.
Number of physical CPUs on the system.

The product's version release identifier. Format is Major.Minor.Update VIM Property: AboutInfo.version https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=ServiceInstance&doPath=content%2eabout
This MIB module provides common datatypes for use in VMWARE enterprise mib modules
VMware, Inc 3401 Hillview Ave Palo Alto, CA 94304 Tel: 1-877-486-9273 or 650-427-5000 Fax: 650-427-5001 Web: http://communities.vmware.com/community/developer/forums/managementapi
This MIB module provides common datatypes for use in VMWARE enterprise mib modules
This MIB module identifies vCenter Trap notifications (traps or inform).
VMware, Inc 3401 Hillview Ave Palo Alto, CA 94304 Tel: 1-877-486-9273 or 650-427-5000 Fax: 650-427-5001 Web: http://communities.vmware.com/community/developer/forums/managementapi
This MIB module identifies vCenter Trap notifications (traps or inform).
This is the name of the vSphere host in the notification.
This is the name of the vSphere host in the notification.
This is the new status in the notification.
This is the new status in the notification.
This is the current object value in the notification.
This is the current object value in the notification.
This is the old status in the notification.
This is the old status in the notification.
This is the current object in the notification. This may be one of esx host name, vm name, or other. This value must not be empty.
This is the current object in the notification. This may be one of esx host name, vm name, or other. This value must not be empty.
This is the alarm target object type.
This is the alarm target object type.
This is the alarm notification type.
This is the alarm notification type.
This is the name of the VM in the notification.
This is the name of the VM in the notification.

This notification is sent on entity alarm state change, by the vCenter Server SNMP agent. This information is also available through the vSphere client, through the Alarms screen, or through the Managed Object Browser(MOB) interface for alarms at https://<vCenter Server machine address>/mob/?moid=AlarmManager. Listing individual objects of a specific type or ID can be done through the PropertyCollector SDK API. See http://www.vmware.com/support/developer/vc-sdk/visdk2xpubs/ReferenceGuide/vmodl.query.PropertyCollector.html for details.

This notification is sent on entity alarm state change, by the vCenter Server SNMP agent. This information is also available through the vSphere client, through the Alarms screen, or through the Managed Object Browser(MOB) interface for alarms at https://<vCenter Server machine address>/mob/?moid=AlarmManager. Listing individual objects of a specific type or ID can be done through the PropertyCollector SDK API. See http://www.vmware.com/support/developer/vc-sdk/visdk2xpubs/ReferenceGuide/vmodl.query.PropertyCollector.html for details.

This notification is sent on entity alarm state change, by the vCenter Server SNMP agent. This information is also available through the vSphere client, through the Alarms screen, or through the Managed Object Browser(MOB) interface for alarms at https://<vCenter Server machine address>/mob/?moid=AlarmManager. Listing individual objects of a specific type or ID can be done through the PropertyCollector SDK API. See http://www.vmware.com/support/developer/vc-sdk/visdk2xpubs/ReferenceGuide/vmodl.query.PropertyCollector.html for details.

This notification is sent on entity alarm state change, by the vCenter Server SNMP agent. This information is also available through the vSphere client, through the Alarms screen, or through the Managed Object Browser(MOB) interface for alarms at https://<vCenter Server machine address>/mob/?moid=AlarmManager. Listing individual objects of a specific type or ID can be done through the PropertyCollector SDK API. See http://www.vmware.com/support/developer/vc-sdk/visdk2xpubs/ReferenceGuide/vmodl.query.PropertyCollector.html for details.

This notification is sent on starting or restarting vCenter Server, on requesting a test notification explicitly, and can also be configured to be sent periodically at a specified time interval via vCenter Server configuration by the vCenter Server SNMP agent.

This notification is sent on starting or restarting vCenter Server, on requesting a test notification explicitly, and can also be configured to be sent periodically at a specified time interval via vCenter Server configuration by the vCenter Server SNMP agent.
This MIB file contains the information that the receiving party needs in order to interpret the SNMP traps sent by vCenter Operations Manager.
VMware, Inc 3401 Hillview Ave Palo Alto, CA 94304 Tel: 1-877-486-9273 or 650-427-5000 Fax: 650-427-5001 Web: http://communities.vmware.com/community/developer/forums/managementapi
This MIB file contains the information that the receiving party needs in order to interpret the SNMP traps sent by vCenter Operations Manager.
The name of the VCOPs server that generated this alert.
The name of the VCOPs server that generated this alert.
A text string describing the alert criticality level.
A text string describing the alert criticality level.
The Entity name about which this alert was generated.
The Entity name about which this alert was generated.
The Entity type about which this alert was generated.
The Entity type about which this alert was generated.
The unique VCOPs identifier of the alert that was generated.
The unique VCOPs identifier of the alert that was generated.
The info message of the alert that was generated.
The info message of the alert that was generated.
A text string describing the root-cause of the alert that was generated.
A text string describing the root-cause of the alert that was generated.
The textual subtype description of the alert that was generated.
The textual subtype description of the alert that was generated.
The timestamp of the alert in UTC format.
The timestamp of the alert in UTC format.
This group is actually the prefix one uses when creating enterprise-specific trap OID's for an SNMPv2 trap. It is used in the VMware MIB when defining traps.
This group is actually the prefix one uses when creating enterprise-specific trap OID's for an SNMPv2 trap. It is used in the VMware MIB when defining traps.
The textual type description of the alert that was generated.
The textual type description of the alert that was generated.
The URL of the 'Alert Summary' page of the alert that was generated.
The URL of the 'Alert Summary' page of the alert that was generated.
This members of this group are the OIDs for VarBinds that contain data for ALL Alerts.
This members of this group are the OIDs for VarBinds that contain data for ALL Alerts.

This MIB module provides for monitoring of inventory and state via polling and notifications of state changes for virtual machines residing on this host system. This MIB module also provides a mapping beween SMI managed objects defined here and their corresponding VMware Virtual Infrastructure Management (VIM) API properties.
VMware, Inc 3401 Hillview Ave Palo Alto, CA 94304 Tel: 1-877-486-9273 or 650-427-5000 Fax: 650-427-5001 Web: http://communities.vmware.com/community/developer/forums/managementapi

This MIB module provides for monitoring of inventory and state via polling and notifications of state changes for virtual machines residing on this host system. This MIB module also provides a mapping beween SMI managed objects defined here and their corresponding VMware Virtual Infrastructure Management (VIM) API properties.
This number corresponds to the vmwVmIdx the vmwVmTable.
This number corresponds to the vmwVmIdx the vmwVmTable.
Reports true if the dvd/cdrom is connected to the virtual machine.
Reports true if the dvd/cdrom is connected to the virtual machine.
Identifies a specific DVD or CDROM drive. Value may change across system reboots.
Identifies a specific DVD or CDROM drive. Value may change across system reboots.
Identifies the specific DVD or CDROM drive.
Identifies the specific DVD or CDROM drive.

Reports the iso or device this virtual drive has been configured to use VIM Property: Virtual Device's with index of 3000-3999 (same as disks) MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2ehardware then select property 'backing' to how this cdrom connects. If no backing was defined by operator, string will start with W: If unavailable, string will start with E:r

Reports the iso or device this virtual drive has been configured to use VIM Property: Virtual Device's with index of 3000-3999 (same as disks) MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2ehardware then select property 'backing' to how this cdrom connects. If no backing was defined by operator, string will start with W: If unavailable, string will start with E:r
Table of DVD or CDROM drives for all vms in vmwVmTable.
Table of DVD or CDROM drives for all vms in vmwVmTable.
Reports 'true' if the floppy drive virtual device is connected to the virtual machine.
Reports 'true' if the floppy drive virtual device is connected to the virtual machine.
Identifies one specific virtual floppy device.
Identifies one specific virtual floppy device.

File or Device that this device is connected to, example /dev/fd0. VIM Property: Virtual Device's with index of 8000-8999. MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2ehardware If no backing was defined by operator, string will start with W: If unavailable, string will start with E:r

File or Device that this device is connected to, example /dev/fd0. VIM Property: Virtual Device's with index of 8000-8999. MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2ehardware If no backing was defined by operator, string will start with W: If unavailable, string will start with E:r
This number corresponds to vmwVmIdx in vmwVmTable.
This number corresponds to vmwVmIdx in vmwVmTable.
Identifies one specific floppy device. May change across system reboots.
Identifies one specific floppy device. May change across system reboots.
Table of floppy drives for all vms in vmwVmTable.
Table of floppy drives for all vms in vmwVmTable.
The name of the hba as it appears in the VM Settings. VIM Property: Virtual Device index of 200-299. MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2ehardware
The name of the hba as it appears in the VM Settings. VIM Property: Virtual Device index of 200-299. MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2ehardware
Identifies a specific storage disk. Index may change across reboots.
Identifies a specific storage disk. Index may change across reboots.
This value identifies a particular disk.
This value identifies a particular disk.
Identifies the disk as seen from the host bus controller VIM Property: Virtual Device's with index of 2000-2999,3000-3999. MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2ehardware
Identifies the disk as seen from the host bus controller VIM Property: Virtual Device's with index of 2000-2999,3000-3999. MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2ehardware
Table of all virtual disks configured for vms in vmwVmTable.
Table of all virtual disks configured for vms in vmwVmTable.
This number corresponds to vmwVmIdx in vmwVmTable.
This number corresponds to vmwVmIdx in vmwVmTable.
The oem host bus adapter hardware being emulated to the Guest OS. MOB: Not visible.
The oem host bus adapter hardware being emulated to the Guest OS. MOB: Not visible.
This number corresponds to the vmwVmIdx in vmwVmTable.
This number corresponds to the vmwVmIdx in vmwVmTable.

Path to the configuration file for this vm expressed as a fully qualified path name in POSIX or DOS extended format VM Config file File name: MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2efiles VM Datastore containing the filename: MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2edatastoreUrl

Path to the configuration file for this vm expressed as a fully qualified path name in POSIX or DOS extended format VM Config file File name: MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2efiles VM Datastore containing the filename: MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2edatastoreUrl
This is the path to the config file of the affected vm generating the trap and is same as vmwVmTable vmwVmConfigFile. It is expressed as POSIX pathname.
This is the path to the config file of the affected vm generating the trap and is same as vmwVmTable vmwVmConfigFile. It is expressed as POSIX pathname.
Number of virtual CPUs assigned to this virtual machine. VIM Property: numCPU MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2ehardware
Number of virtual CPUs assigned to this virtual machine. VIM Property: numCPU MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2ehardware
Name by which this vm is displayed. It is not guaranteed to be unique. MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=summary%2eguest
Name by which this vm is displayed. It is not guaranteed to be unique. MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=summary%2eguest
Identifies a registered VM on this ESX system.
Identifies a registered VM on this ESX system.

Operating system running on this vm. This value corresponds to the value specified when creating the VM and unless set correctly may differ from the actual OS running. Will return one of the values if set in order: Vim.Vm.GuestInfo.guestFullName Vim.Vm.GuestInfo.guestId Vim.Vm.GuestInfo.guestFamily MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=guest where moid = vmwVmIdx. If VMware Tools is not running, value will be of form 'E: error message'

Operating system running on this vm. This value corresponds to the value specified when creating the VM and unless set correctly may differ from the actual OS running. Will return one of the values if set in order: Vim.Vm.GuestInfo.guestFullName Vim.Vm.GuestInfo.guestId Vim.Vm.GuestInfo.guestFamily MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=guest where moid = vmwVmIdx. If VMware Tools is not running, value will be of form 'E: error message'

Operation mode of guest operating system. Values include: running - Guest is running normally. shuttingdown - Guest has a pending shutdown command. resetting - Guest has a pending reset command. standby - Guest has a pending standby command. notrunning - Guest is not running. unknown - Guest information is not available. VIM Property: guestState MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=guest

Operation mode of guest operating system. Values include: running - Guest is running normally. shuttingdown - Guest has a pending shutdown command. resetting - Guest has a pending reset command. standby - Guest has a pending standby command. notrunning - Guest is not running. unknown - Guest information is not available. VIM Property: guestState MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=guest
Uniquely identifies a given virtual machine host bus adapter.
Uniquely identifies a given virtual machine host bus adapter.
Uniquely identifies a given Host Bus adapter in this VM. May change across system reboots.
Uniquely identifies a given Host Bus adapter in this VM. May change across system reboots.
Table of host bus adapters (hba) for all vms in vmwVmTable.
Table of host bus adapters (hba) for all vms in vmwVmTable.
This holds the same value as vmwVmVMID of the affected vm generating the trap. to allow polling of the affected vm in vmwVmTable.
This holds the same value as vmwVmVMID of the affected vm generating the trap. to allow polling of the affected vm in vmwVmTable.

An operational identifier given the VM when registered on this ESX system. The value is not unique across ESX systems and may change upon reboot. VIM property: ha-vm-folder MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=ha%2dfolder%2dvm A given Virtual Machine Instance can be queried using this URL: MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx

An operational identifier given the VM when registered on this ESX system. The value is not unique across ESX systems and may change upon reboot. VIM property: ha-vm-folder MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=ha%2dfolder%2dvm A given Virtual Machine Instance can be queried using this URL: MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx

Reports the configured virtual hardware MAC address. If VMware Tools is not running, or VM has not yet been powered on for the first time and mac is to be generated by VM then the value is zero'd out/empty. VIM Property: Virtual Device's with index of 4000-4999. MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2ehardware

Reports the configured virtual hardware MAC address. If VMware Tools is not running, or VM has not yet been powered on for the first time and mac is to be generated by VM then the value is zero'd out/empty. VIM Property: Virtual Device's with index of 4000-4999. MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2ehardware
Memory configured for this virtual machine. Memory > MAX Integer32 is reported as max integer32. VIM Property: memoryMB MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2ehardware
Memory configured for this virtual machine. Memory > MAX Integer32 is reported as max integer32. VIM Property: memoryMB MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config%2ehardware

Do not use this value, and should an agent return it discard it.

Reports 'true' if the ethernet virtual device is connected to the virtual machine.

Identifies a particular nic for the specified vmwVmIdx
Identifies a unique network adapter in this table. Not guaranteed to be the same across system reboots.

A table containing information on virtual machines that have been configured on the system.
A table containing information on virtual machines that have been configured on the system.

A unique identifier for this VM. Must be unique across a set of ESX systems managed by an instance of vSphere Center. Example value: 564d95d4-bff7-31fd-f20f-db2d808a8b32 VIM Property: uuid MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config

A unique identifier for this VM. Must be unique across a set of ESX systems managed by an instance of vSphere Center. Example value: 564d95d4-bff7-31fd-f20f-db2d808a8b32 VIM Property: uuid MOB: https://esx.example.com/mob/?moid=vmwVmIdx&doPath=config
No longer provided, use vmwVmIdx. See vmwVmUUID for cross system, unique, persistent identifier.
No longer provided, use vmwVmIdx. See vmwVmUUID for cross system, unique, persistent identifier.

This trap is sent when a virtual machine detects or regains the required number of guest heartbeats for a given period of time. This is only sent if VMware tools are installed in the Guest OS. Upon receiving this notification client applications should poll the vmwVmTable to obtain current status.

This trap is sent when a virtual machine detects or regains the required number of guest heartbeats for a given period of time. This is only sent if VMware tools are installed in the Guest OS. Upon receiving this notification client applications should poll the vmwVmTable to obtain current status.

This trap is sent when a virtual machine detects a loss in guest heartbeat. The Guest heartbeat is only sent if VMware Tools are installed in the Guest OS. Control process will send this event whenever it determines the number of guest heartbeats for a given period of time have not been received. Upon receiving this notification client applications should poll the vmwVmTable to obtain current status.

This trap is sent when a virtual machine detects a loss in guest heartbeat. The Guest heartbeat is only sent if VMware Tools are installed in the Guest OS. Control process will send this event whenever it determines the number of guest heartbeats for a given period of time have not been received. Upon receiving this notification client applications should poll the vmwVmTable to obtain current status.

This trap is sent when a virtual machine is powered off. The origin of this event can be several: for instance may be operator initiated, vmx process terminating abnormally. NOTE: vms powered down due to VMotion are not reported. Upon receiving this notification client applications should poll the vmwVmTable to obtain current status.

This trap is sent when a virtual machine is powered off. The origin of this event can be several: for instance may be operator initiated, vmx process terminating abnormally. NOTE: vms powered down due to VMotion are not reported. Upon receiving this notification client applications should poll the vmwVmTable to obtain current status.

This trap is sent when a virtual machine is powered on from a suspended or a powered off state. The origin of this event can be several: for instance may be operator initiated, existing vmx process reconnects to control subsystem. NOTE: vms powered up due to VMotion are not reported. Upon receiving this notification client applications should poll the vmwVmTable to obtain current status.

This trap is sent when a virtual machine is powered on from a suspended or a powered off state. The origin of this event can be several: for instance may be operator initiated, existing vmx process reconnects to control subsystem. NOTE: vms powered up due to VMotion are not reported. Upon receiving this notification client applications should poll the vmwVmTable to obtain current status.

This trap is sent when a virtual machine is suspended. The origin of this event may be several: operator initiated, by software api clients, and by other means. Upon receiving this notification client applications should poll the vmwVmTable to obtain current status.

This trap is sent when a virtual machine is suspended. The origin of this event may be several: operator initiated, by software api clients, and by other means. Upon receiving this notification client applications should poll the vmwVmTable to obtain current status.
